title: Gudhi Padwa
summary: Gudhi Padwa is a significant spring festival that marks the lunisolar new year for Marathi and Konkani Hindus. Celebrated primarily in Maharashtra, Goa, and Daman at the beginning of Chaitra, the first month of the lunisolar Hindu calendar, it is characterized by vibrant traditions. Festivities include creating colourful rangoli floor decorations, erecting a special 'gudhi dhvaja' adorned with cloth, flowers, mango/neem leaves, and a sugar crystal garland (gathi), topped with upturned vessels. Celebrations also feature street gatherings, dancing, and festive foods. While a new year for many, it is not universal for all Hindus, as some communities like those in Gujarat observe their new year during Diwali.
key_points: Gudhi Padwa is the lunisolar new year for Marathi and Konkani Hindus.
It is celebrated in Maharashtra, Goa, and Daman at the start of the lunisolar Hindu month of Chaitra.
Key celebration elements include rangoli, gudhi dhvaja (decorated staff), gathi (sugar crystal garland), festive foods, street gatherings, and dancing.
The festival is known by various names across different communities, including Ugadi (Kannada/Telugu Hindus), Cheti Chand (Sindhi people), and Navreh (Kashmiri Pandits).
It is not the universal new year for all Hindus, with some, like those in Gujarat, celebrating during Diwali (Bestu Varas).
timeline: Marks the start of the lunisolar new year.
Celebrated at the beginning of Chaitra, the first month of the lunisolar Hindu calendar.
Coincides with Ugadi for Kannada and Telugu Hindus.
Observed as Cheti Chand by Sindhi people, marking the emergence of Jhulelal.
Celebrated as Navreh by Kashmiri Pandits on the first day of the bright half of Chaitra.
important_figures: Goddess Sharika (form of Durga/Shakti, worshipped by Kashmiri Pandits)
applications: Creation of colourful rangoli floor decorations.
Erecting a special 'gudhi dhvaja' with specific adornments (sari/dhoti, flowers, mango/neem leaves, gathi, upturned vessels).
Preparation and consumption of festive foods like tahiri (sweet rice) and sai bhaji.
Organizing street gatherings and cultural dancing.
Offering prayers to deities like Jhulelal (Sindhi) or Goddess Sharika (Kashmiri Pandits).
current_status: Gudhi Padwa continues to be a widely celebrated spring festival and new year for Marathi, Konkani, and other Hindu communities across Maharashtra, Goa, Daman, Karnataka, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh, and among Sindhi and Kashmiri Pandit populations.
